translated: The Three Jewels Chronicle, Volume 1, Imperial Years and Dynasties, Zhou, Qin
Submitted by the Imperial Erudite Fei Changfang in the 17th year of the Kaihuang era
As for the imperial years (Zhou, Qin), it is said that the Tathagata was born in the country of Shendu, which was during the time of King Ji
of the Zhou Dynasty in China.
As the years passed, the human world became increasingly different.
Pointing to it, one would quickly be confused about the sequence of events.
Now, first, the Jiazi cycle is arranged above, connecting the ancient and modern times.
Below, the imperial years are compiled, outlining the eras.
The succession of rulers and hegemons will be like a mirror in front of one's eyes.
The changes in dynasties will be like a reflection in the palm of one's hand.
Then, the kings will be examined for their blessings and governance.

The Buddha's teachings will be spread in accordance with the times, responding to the capacities of beings and benefiting them.ğŸ”½The principles of the Buddhist scriptures and Confucian teachings will be in accord and mysteriously in harmony.
It can be said that the spiritual descent is from the five heavens and the auspicious communication is from the nine states.
The mother of King Ji Chang of the Zhou Dynasty dreamed of a great man and gave birth to him.
He had a dragon face, tiger eyebrows, and a height of one zhang.
There were four nipples on his chest.
The country borders the Western Rong.
The government extends to the East.
A red sparrow brought blessings.ğŸ”½It was renamed Zhou.
He was given the posthumous title of King Wen.
He moved the capital to Feng and buried the withered bones.
The world submitted to him.
Therefore, Confucius said:
The virtue of King Wen is beautiful.
He transformed without moving.
When his son King Wu attacked Zhou,
He moved the capital to Haojing.
On the way, he met a thirsty man and got off his carriage to fan him.
He loved the people of the empire as if they were his own children.
Therefore, the Sunzi said:
When King Wu was born, the world sang.
When he died, the four seas wept.
In the tenth year of King Zhuang's reign, in the fourth month of summer in the seventh year of Duke Zhuang's Spring and Autumn Annals, on the Xinmao day of the night, the stars were not seen.
In the middle of the night, stars fell like rain.
According to this, it was the time when the Tathagata was born in the royal palace. The sages of the pastæ¨ä½›ç”Ÿå¹´æ¨ the year of the Buddha's birth, each had different opinions about the distance.
According to Faxian's record, the Buddha was born in the 26th year of the Jiawu cycle of the Yin dynasty, the 26th year of King Wu Ding's reign.
Up to the Dingsi year of the 17th year of the Kaihuang era, it has been 1,681 years.
According to the answers of the Å›ramaá¹‡a Fashang to the questions of the state of Goguryeo,
it was the Jiayin year, the 24th year of King Zhao's reign of the Zhou dynasty, the fifth ruler of the Zhou dynasty.
Up to the Dingsi year, it has been 1,486 years.ğŸ”½Citing the separate biography of King Mu of the Zhou dynasty as evidence,
it is said that King Mu's son, Man, succeeded to the throne.
King Mu heard that the Buddha was born in Kapilavastu.
He then traveled west and did not return.
According to the Record of Images and Realities, it was the Wuyin year, the 48th year of King Ping's reign of the Zhou dynasty, the 17th ruler of the Zhou dynasty.
Up to the Dingsi year, it has been 1,323 years.
According to the Å›ramaá¹‡a Shi Dao'an of the Later Zhou dynasty, using the chronology of KumÄrajÄ«va and the inscriptions on stone pillars,
it was the Eichou year, the 5th year of King Huan's reign of the Zhou dynasty, the 18th ruler of the Zhou dynasty.
Up to the present year Dingsi, it has been 1,225 years.
Based on what Zhao Bo-Xiu obtained in the first year of the Liang Dynasty's Datong era when he met with Vinaya Master Hongdu at Mount Lu, it can beæ¨.
It corresponds to the second year of Jiaxu, the second year of the reign of King Zhending Liang of the Zhou Dynasty.
Up to the present year Dingsi, it has been approximately 1,161 years.
This is the most recent.
According to the teachings of the Tripiá¹­aka and the Saá¹ƒghabhedavastu,
why did the Buddha not ordain women?
It is for the sake of respecting the Dharma.
The true Dharma will last for a thousand years.
Ordaining women will reduce it by five hundred years. Practicing the eight precepts will make it full again for a thousand years.
After that, the semblance Dharma will also last for a thousand years.
The final Dharma will last for ten thousand years.
For the first five thousand years, one can study the three kinds of penetrating wisdom and attain the four fruits.
For the next six thousand years, one can study but will not attain the Way.
After ten thousand years, the scriptures and texts will naturally disappear.
There will only be those who shave their heads and wear the kaá¹£Äya robe.
In the age of the true Dharma, the taste of the Mahayana is pure.
By the time of the semblance Dharma, the taste is slightly diluted.
If we enter the degenerate Dharma, then there is no Mahayana.
Slaves and servants leave home and pollute pure conduct.
Evil kings rule the world and tax monks and nuns.
Now it is not so.
Because this is the transition between the true and semblance Dharmas, it is not yet deep.
The Three Jewels flourish and the Mahayana spreads widely.
How can it be said that we have already entered the degenerate Dharma?
Now, relying on the Sutra of the Wise and Foolish and other sutras, I collate the Lu history.
I lightly raise one corner and respectfully leave it for future sages.
I hope that the sacred traces will be proclaimed and entrusted to skillful means.
The Buddha, in the ninth year of King Zhuang's reign, on the eighth day of the fourth month in the Gui Si year,
appeared in the form of a white elephant and descended from Tuá¹£ita Heaven to the right side of King Åšuddhodana's chief wife MÄyÄ in the city of Kapilavastu in Central India.
At that time, the gods secretly guarded her in the womb.
The secret was hidden from the worldly eye, and few knew about it.
On the eighth day of the second month in the second spring of the tenth year, when the ghost star was in conjunction,
In the Lumbini Grove, under a sal tree, he was born from his mother's right side.
After the birth, the auspicious signs appeared.
Therefore, the Sutra of Universal Radiance says:
Emitting a great light that illuminates the three thousand worlds.
This is what the Zuozhuan describes as:
The stars not appearing at night, but the night being bright.
The Sutra of Auspicious Apparitions says:
The star of Jupiter appears below, accompanying the birth of the Crown Prince.
Therefore, the Zuozhuan says: Stars falling like rain.
The Sutra of the Past Activities of the Buddha says:
In the sky, without clouds, it rains naturally.
Du's annotations say: At that time, there were no clouds.
The Zuozhuan also says:
Accompanying the rain.
However, the Ji Zhou calendar takes the eleventh month as the correct month.
Saying the fourth month is the second month of the lunar calendar, on the fifth day of the lunar month, the Xinmao day.
The Lu historian's mistake.
The monk Dao'an wrote the Treatise on the Two Teachings.
Using the Ji calendar to calculate, it still matches the eighth day.
Only taking the time of birth as the year of enlightenment.
It causes the Buddha's world to be thirty years distant.
The Buddha reached the first year of King Xi's reign, the Gengzi year, at the age of seven.
At the age of ten, in the year of Guimao, he rode a sheep-drawn carriage to the school.
At the age of fourteen, in the year of Dingwei, he competed with his peers in strength.
At the age of fifteen, in the year of Bingxu, he went to the capital to study.
At the age of seventeen, in the year of Gengxu, he married Princess Jili.
At the age of nineteen, in the year of Renzi, on the eighth day of the fourth month, he left home in the middle of the night and went to the twelve places. The Sutra of the Twelve Travels says:
The Buddha left home at the age of twenty.
The second volume of the Ekottarika Ä€gama says:
I was twenty-nine years old.
I left home in order to save people.
It also says:
At the age of twenty, I studied with the non-Buddhists.
The Chang ahan jing also says:
At the age of twenty-nine, I left home.
If we infer from the general principles, the Buddha lived for seventy-nine years.
If he left home at twenty-nine and attained enlightenment at thirty-five,
He could only have taught for forty-five years.
However, the Chan Essentials Sutra says:
Shakyamuni taught and transformed sentient beings for forty-nine years.
Many sutras say:
He left home at nineteen.
I now take this as correct.
If he left home at twenty-nine and attained enlightenment at thirty-five,
it seems to be lacking in the sutras.
It just says:
He studied with non-Buddhist teachers for twenty years.
That would mean he attained enlightenment fifty years later.
We know this is mistaken.
At nineteen, in the year Guihai, at thirty,
on the eighth day of the second month, when the morning star appeared,
he suddenly awakened and attained supreme enlightenment. The lower fascicle of the Nirvana Sutra says:
The Buddha said to Ananda:
Since I attained enlightenment, it has been forty-nine years.
The Buddha is difficult to encounter.
Only after one billion four hundred thousand years will there be Maitreya.
The Chan Essentials says:
The Tathagata attained enlightenment forty-nine years ago.
This is the one flavor.
The fifth fascicle of the Chang Ahan Sutra says:
The Buddha said to Subhadra:
Since I attained Buddhahood, it has been fifty years. For forty-nine years, I have been in the heavens, among humans, dragons, and spirits, in the world.
Preaching the Dharma and teaching, causing each to attain liberation and realize the four fruits.
Those who go against the current are as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River.
Those who escape the three evil paths and are reborn in the heavens and among humans are innumerable.
When the conditions of sentient beings are exhausted,
The Buddha, in the fourth year of Kuangwang, on the fifteenth day of the second month, in the latter night,
Entered parinirvÄá¹‡a in the city of KuÅ›inagara in the middle country.
Since then, up to the seventeenth year of Kaihuang in the present dynasty, the Dingsi year,
It has been 1,205 years. The eyes of the world have disappeared. The Nirvana Sutra and the Vinaya in Ten Recitations both say it was the fifteenth day of the second month.
The Sutra of the Bodhisattva's Entry into the Womb says:
On the eighth day of the second month, he entered nirvÄá¹‡a.
It also says:
From his initial birth, attaining the Way, up to nirvÄá¹‡a, it was all on the eighth day of the fourth month.
The old translations by former sages all say:
It must be the second month.
The reason is this.
RÄjagá¹›ha is three thousand li away from the city of KuÅ›inagara.
Seven days after the Buddha's nirvÄá¹‡a, his disciples scattered.
KÄÅ›yapa was heading to RÄjagá¹›ha to gather the Dharma canon for the summer retreat.
The great assembly he brought, both the wise and the foolish, all arrived at RÄjagá¹›ha, and only then did they examine and select.
It was not possible to reach their destination on the same day.
Yet all the other sÅ«tras say that the nirvÄá¹‡a was at midnight.
Only the Saá¹ƒghabhedavastu says it was at dawn.
The sÅ«tras explain the nirvÄá¹‡a.
The time has a clear meaning.
It shows sentient beings leaving the Buddha's sun.
It must be in the night division. If it is the first watch,
the time is not yet dawn.
It shows that the next Buddha will appear in the world after a long time.
If it is in the middle watch,
the time is exactly the same.
In the last watch,
the Buddha will appear before long.
Maitreya still has a hundred million years.
Moreover, it is not in a different kalpa.
The middle watch is reasonable.
The AÅ›okÄvadÄna says:
One hundred and sixteen years after the Buddha's nirvana,
there was a king of JambudvÄ«pa named AÅ›oka.
He came from East India and ruled the city of PÄá¹­aliputra.
He collected the Buddha's relics and built 84,000 jeweled stupas,
covering all of JambudvÄ«pa.
If one wishes to briefly speak of the spread of Buddhism to India,
it can be said that in the cities and towns along the Yangtze and Han rivers, in the western and eastern regions of the Guannei and Longxi commanderies, there are stupas everywhere.
At that time, it was the twenty-sixth year of the reign of King Jing of Zhou, the dingwei year.
From King Wu to King Ping, thirty-nine kings reigned for 884 years.
The capital was Feng and Hao, and Luoyang.
The Zhou dynasty had four capitals in total.
King Zhao of Qin established the state for fifty-two years and destroyed Zhou, calling it Qin.
He changed the capital Haojing to Xianyang.
He then made it his capital.
In the twenty-sixth year of the reign of the first emperor of Qin, the fourth ruler,
he eliminated the six states.
In the twenty-seventh year, he abolished the nine states.
The empire was divided into thirty-six prefectures.
In the thirty-fourth year, all the scriptures were burned.
Only medical prescriptions and techniques were not burned.
Everything else was reduced to ashes.
Therefore, the sacred teachings and spiritual traces of the Zhou Dynasty,
as well as the stupas built by King AÅ›oka to enshrine relics,
were all lost and no one knew their origins.
Moreover, during the time of the First Emperor of Qin,
there were eighteen wise monks such as Shi Lifan,
who brought scriptures and spread the teachings.
The First Emperor did not follow them.
He imprisoned Lifan and others.
At night, a six-foot tall golden person came and broke them out of prison.
The First Emperor was terrified and bowed to them, apologizing.
After forty-nine years, the Qin Dynasty was destroyed by the Han.
It began in the Jiawu year, the first year of King Wu of Zhou, and ended in the Jiayin year when the Second Emperor of Qin was defeated.
In between, there were 933 years.
There were forty-two rulers.
The Zhou Dynasty had sixteen kings for 453 years.
Before the Buddha's birth, the names were not recorded.
Starting from King Zhuang, when the Tathagata was born, it was recorded in the Han dynasty.
Twenty-six rulers, four hundred and eighty-one years.
In summary, it is recorded as the Zhou and Qin dynasties.
It clarifies that the Buddha's vehicle should teach and reach the East.

On the peak of Gayashira, he expounded the Dharma for the dragons and ghosts, which is the same as Elephant Head Mountain. In the fifth year, in the Dingmao year, Shariputra became a Brahmin.
He saw the Buddha's disciple, the monk Masui, and asked:
